content: Quantitative and Systems Biology Program | OHSU Background image: scenic view of downtown portland from tram platform on Marquam hill Quantitative and Systems Biology The Quantitative and Systems Biology Program is a hub for multiple OHSU units pursuing biomedical challenges using systematic computational approaches. Why quantitative and systems biology? Daniel M. Zuckerman, Ph.D., QSB Program Director The transformation of modern biomedicine into a set of increasingly quantitative and interconnected fields provides the driving force for the Program in Quantitative and Systems Biology (QSB) as a point of convergence for multiple OHSU units focused on the study of complex (patho)physiological systems across length and time scales. A systems understanding is essential for identification of emergent pathways in numerous arenas of bioscience: neuroscience, cardiovascular systems, metabolism, and oncology, to name just a few. The program aims to synergize research and education across OHSU, and with partner institutions, in the development and application of quantitative and systems approaches to a wide range of basic and translational biomedical problems. Read more about Dr. Saunders' fellowship Research across OHSU The QSB Program is proud to embrace members from across many departments and centers at OHSU and beyond.  These units represent a broad spectrum of research interests, united by use of modern computational and systems approaches to biomedical investigation.  Participating units include: Biomedical Engineering Department Cancer Early Detection Advanced Research Center (CEDAR) Department of Medical Informatics & Clinical Epidemiology Pacific Northwest National Laboratory Center for Ophthalmic Optics & Lasers (COOL) Vollum Institute Advanced Imaging Research Center Chemical Physiology and Biochemistry
